body_content.explanation: (of fruit or vegetables) the quality of being fresh, firm, and pleasant to eat:
examples: Celery loses its crispness when it is no longer good to eat.
The broccoli was cooked to the right degree of crispness.

body_content.explanation: (of cooked foods such as pastry and biscuits) the quality of having been cooked well enough to be dry and hard in a pleasant way:
examples: The skins can be left on the potatoes for extra crispness.
For maximum crispness, cook the pizza on a pizza stone.

body_content.explanation: (of cloth or paper) the quality of being stiff and smooth:
examples: Damp clothes had dried to a crispness over a string line in the kitchen.
The e-book's screen is designed to replicate the crispness of a paper page.

body_content.explanation: (of an image or sound) the quality of being very clear:
examples: Two factors determine the crispness of the computer image.
Her performance was memorable for the purity and crispness of her tone.

body_content.explanation: (of a way of speaking, writing, or behaving) the quality of being quick, confident, and effective:
examples: His writing lacks the crispness it once had.
The storytelling loses its crispness in the final half-hour.

body_content.explanation: (of the air) the quality of being cold, dry, and fresh:
examples: The day darkened to night and they inhaled the slight crispness of the air.
the perfect crispness of an October night
